20. I’m also not going to stop looking for a solution – giving up isn’t what we were sent here to do.
19. I’m not going to give up on repealing the Unaffordable Care Act. American families deserve better.
18. I truly believe we all want what’s best for our nation and her people. To me, that’s finding a better solution than the ACA provides.
17. But here’s what I’m not doing – I’m not going to impugn the intentions of people who disagree
16. You can’t just put your head in the sand and ignore those facts and hope that it lives forever
15. Its price tag grew and grew from the billions into the trillions, and finally scoring agencies just gave up
14. The ACA is not sustainable, and hasn’t been from the beginning. Its foundation was built on certain groups that never signed up
13. I remain committed to repealing the ACA and replacing it with a system that works for all families
12. So that’s where we stand today. A bad program that has grown deep roots, and a bitterly divided political culture.
11. We’ve got to realize that our pattern should not be disagree and destroy, but rather disagree and solve
10. And two – along the way we stopped fighting the policy, and started fighting the people behind it
9. No matter how badly the program serves (or doesn’t serve) the people – replacing an entitlement is hard
8. The ACA went into effect, and – “A government bureau is the nearest thing to eternal life we’ll ever see on this earth” (Reagan)
7. Two things happened along the way to where we stand today
6. These are facts – you can’t argue with them. And that’s not how our health care system should work
5. Not everyone got to keep their doctors, and they weren’t able to keep their plans
4. Millions are paying for insurance they don’t want. In SC, more than 100,000 stuck without an option
3. In South Carolina, we’re down to one insurer offering plans on the exchanges.We’re seeing triple digit premium hikes,sky high deductibles
2. The debt continues to grow, and the ACA is not getting any better. The former isn’t helped by the latter.
1.When I was elected to Congress in 2010–along w/a record-breaking Freshman class,the major platform was repealing the ACA&the national debt

Perhaps you should listen to the entire speech, where I say EVERY Senator should read her letter.
I work every single day to help ensure kids growing up like I did - poor, single parent families -  can realize their hopes and dreams.
Our #SenateOpportunityCoalition works to listen to folks in communities back home, and find community-powered solutions for poverty.
My #OpportunityAgenda works to bring the American Dream to every family & community through education, job training and community investment

It is a life long passion for me, and I am committed to working for ALL of our kids.
I want true reform that strengthens public education and gives parents a choice for their childrens’ future.
So while some want to continue to put band-aids on a system that isn’t working for a lot of kids, I do not.
Because without education, incarceration rates go up, unemployment goes up, lifetime earnings go down.
We will work with Secretary DeVos to strengthen all of our schools, and to make sure quality education is available to all.
Let’s be clear-there are 1000s of low performing schools across this nation. You can hold the floor forever…but it won’t change that fact
The fact remains no Secretary of Education has the power to “destroy public schools” - and no one would.
We need strong public schools, as well as strong options for parents to choose the best option for their kids.
I am thankful for all the calls, for the passion we’ve seen about education policy for the past two weeks.

6. There is amazing work being done in communities across our nation every day, but their efforts aren’t always recognized by policymakers.
5. We’re engaging communities, learning about solutions from the ground up instead of trying force them from the top down.
4. We’ve brought together the #SenateOpportunityCoalition to help change that.
3. We have created a poverty floor, but not the opportunities needed for every family in every community to find success.
2. The solutions of the past 50 years, while well intentioned, simply have not gotten that job done.
1. We need 21st century solutions to battle poverty and ensure opportunity for all.

16. God Bless, and I hope you all have a great day. Remember - if you want to walk on water, you have got to get out of the boat.
15. Your passion, dedication and love are the heartbeat of this nation - and underscore what could happen when we stand united.
14. For my mom, my granddad, and everyone else who sacrificed so much so the next generation could live a better life - I say thank you.
13. I am working every day to bring quality education, good jobs & the American Dream back to those who may not have experienced them yet
12. That vision must continue to guide us into the future. To truly help us all, we must offer a hand to those in need.
11. Our great nation was built on the dreams and ideals of a group of people who recognized that all men are created equal
10. We can come together, and invest in our communities, encourage private dollars to help rebuild and restore.
9. Let’s recognize the manufacturing boom in states like SC, and reemphasize technical training, apprenticeships, and good, well paying jobs
8. Every child must have access to a quality education. Unemployment, incarceration, dropout rates - all linked to educational achievement
7. To turn back on the light at the end of the tunnel, and strengthen our nation from the ground up.
6. And so, its up to us to bring it back to those millions of families across America who are desperately seeking a chance at success
5. When you can’t see beyond your own block, when you don’t know what’s possible, the American Dream starts to fade.
4. I grew up in a place like that, and have seen both the short- and long-term effects this can bring.
3. While we are the greatest nation on earth, we still have too many people living in poverty and in communities where hope has evaporated
2. We must stand together, move forward together, and find solutions together.
1. I stand for opportunity. For the belief that every single person in this country has greatness inside them waiting to be unleashed.

6. Thank you all once again for the support this week, and even if we disagree, we must sit down and find solutions. Period. God Bless.
5. As I said yesterday, my family has gone from cotton to Congress in one lifetime. That’s the nation we should be…that we need.
4. We’re only going to solve this together. As the American family. Must have painful, but necessary conversations that lead to action.
3. We can stand in support of our law enforcement AND acknowledge the challenges before us. It does not have to be an either/or proposition.
2. We must remember that no matter our frustration, reacting to violence with violence only leads to more heartache.

The bottom line is we can & must do better. Building a bigger Washington doesn’t help America. Ensuring opportunity builds a better America.
I will work anytime, any place, anywhere, with anyone to tackle the issues facing our poor and low-income communities.
These are hardworking families, many of which simply need the opportunity in order to succeed.
When you bring education and jobs, you bring hope and concrete evidence of success. Through investment, we sustain that success.
As we build on these three pillars - education, jobs and community investment, we can make a huge difference for the poor.
My #CHOICEAct ensures that parents have the opportunity to ensure their kids get the best education, regardless of their zip code.
My LEAP Act w/@CoryBooker incentivizes apprenticeships, so folks can earn while they learn. Also encourages manufacturing skills.

My Investing in Opportunity Act encourages private investment in low-income communities w/no new govt program. https://www.scott.senate.gov/press-release/senator-scott-introduces-bipartisan-legislation-stimulate-local-economies-impoverished … #IIOA
My #OpportunityAgenda seeks to do just that. Empower people, not bureaucrats. Encourage success, not stagnation.
Its not through more government, but through shaping a system that encourages success.
What I’m looking for is how do we empower people. How do we put hope back into our childrens' minds. How do we kickstart the American Dream.
Too often people get tangled in the safety net, instead of bouncing back towards success. That’s a fault of the system in place.
I know that while our current system might have created a poverty floor, it has not widely created opportunities for success.
Having to use the oven to heat your house; watching your grandmother walk 8 miles a day because we couldn't afford the bus - that’s tough.
Growing up in a poor, single parent household, I know firsthand the struggles folks in low-income communities go through every day.
Too often over the past 50 years, our answers to fighting poverty have relied on empowering government instead of people.

Today’s rule simply reinforces the fact that the board must return to acting as the neutral arbiter it was intended to be.
In South Carolina we have seen the potential ramifications that come as the result of a wildly partisan NLRB.
It also requires an unprecedented amount personal information to be given to union reps, such as personal cell phones and email addresses.
Ambush elections hurt the ability of employees to make a well-informed choice on joining a union,give limited time to hear both sides.
Today’s rule issued by the NLRB is perhaps the most pro-union action taken by the current administration, which is quite a feat in itself.

Ashton Carter has a wealth of experience that I hope will lead to solid decision making and long-term strategic thinking.
